title: Relative Clauses All 2
instructions: Complete the sentences with the appropriate relative pronoun, B1whichB2, B1thatB2, B1whoB2, B1whomB2, B1nothingB2 or B1whatB2.

sentence: you said about the project, I have a few questions to ask.
explain: Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so 'which' or 'that' is not correct.

sentence: is why they don't want to fulfill our contract.
explain: Corr: which. We refer back to a whole sentence, and there's a comma, too, so 'that' is not correct.
Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so 'which' and 'that' are not correct.

sentence: was a Mini) would be 25 years old today.
explain: Corr: which. It's a non-defining relative clause, it is separated by brackets, so here 'that' is not correct. We refer back to a noun (a Mini), so we cannot use 'what'.

sentence: Can you give me a document
explain: Corr: which or that. We refer back to a noun (a document), so we cannot use 'what'. As the relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, we cannot leave it out.
Corr: what. Here we do not refer back to a noun. The relative clause is the object of a preposition (about).

sentence: we're going to see a film about takes place in the future.
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. We refer back to a noun (the story), so we cannot use 'what'. As the relative pronoun is the not the subject of the relative clause, we can leave it out. The subject is 'we'.

sentence: They didn't invite us to their wedding,
may mean that they hate us.
explain: Corr: which. Here we don't refer back to a noun, but we refer back to the whole sentnece. In such cases only 'which' is correct, and a comma is used before it.

Corr: that or which. We need to include a relative pronoun because it's the subject of the relative clause. We refer back to a noun (everything), so we cannot use 'what'. Because of 'everything', 'that' is a better solution than 'which'. The use of 'which' would sound quite unnatural.

sentence: Jenny sees in George. He's the meanest guy
explain: Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so we cannot use 'that' or 'which'.
Corr: who, whom, that or nothing. Here we refer back to a person, so 'what' is not correct. As the relative pronoun is not subject of the relative clause, we can leave it out.

sentence: came from the street made me crazy.
explain: Corr: which or that. We refer back to a noun (noise), so we cannot use 'what'. The relative pronoun is the subject of the relative clause, so we cannot leave it out.
